intro: Retinispora glaucescens, commonly known as the blue-green retinispora, is a member of the Rhodophyceae class, which includes red algae. It is characterized by its bluish-green coloration, which results from the presence of phycobilins and chlorophyll. This species typically grows in marine environments, attaching itself to substrates such as rocks or other algae. Its structure consists of filaments that branch into dense, gelatinous mats. Retinispora glaucescens plays a role in marine ecosystems by contributing to nutrient cycling and providing habitat for small aquatic organisms.
